timeline.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: We should think about combining latestWorkflowColumnFamily and digestByIdColumnFamily. Both column families are mapped by the BPMN process id (here called workflowId). One column family stores the latest version number of the workflow and the other stores the digest of the latest workflow.
timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText: I tried to do this but it's not very nice since they're used in different contexts it's not very easy to join them. The digest is only read and written during the workflow transformation but the version is often used in the engine so by uniting them we'd be constantly reading the digest unnecessarily. They're also written in different places, the digest is written during the transformation and the version is put in with the deployment. I'm not sure if that needs to stay like that or maybe it can be refactored
replies.author: MiguelPires

replies.bodyText: I don't see a problem that the properties are written and read in different places. I agree that reading the digest if it is not needed, feels not right. On the other side, having another column family may cost a lot of memory. But I'm not sure what is better here. Let's wait on the RocksDB investigation results of Chris.
replies.author: saig0

timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure about this. Unless we change the db to only take msgpack format instead of DbValues, this doesn't give us much right? And we don't want to force the db values to be msgpack since in the future we might want a column family with a different format for whatever reason (even if it has different backwards compat properties). But I agree we can delete some of the DbValue implementations that are not also DbKeys.
replies.author: MiguelPires

timeline.bodyText: We increment or decrement a property in different places. What about implementing both functions in  IntegerProperty/LongProperty?
timeline.author: saig0
saig0
saig0
saig0
saig0
saig0

timeline.bodyText: We have multiple of these value objects which just wraps the record in it. What do you think about having only one wrapper class?
timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText: The ObjectProperty needs a record object so we need to know the type. Besides, this way if we want to add something to the state we just have to add a property, so I guess it's easier for the future
replies.author: MiguelPires

timeline.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText:
No more upgrade tests 😂
We should remember to enable the test again at some point.
timeline.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText:
We implemented this copy method in different records. What about implementing this in a generic way?
In the ObjectValue/UnpackedObject class, we have access to all properties and could copy the values.
timeline.author: saig0

timeline.message: chore(engine): use msgpack in element instance state
chore(engine): use msgpack in deployment state
chore(engine): use msgpack in incident state
chore(engine): use msgpack in timer state
chore(engine): use msgpack in job state
chore(engine): use msgpack in variable state
chore(engine): use msgpack in next value state
chore(engine): use msgpack in msg state
chore(engine): use msgpack in msg subscription state
chore(engine): use msgpack in wf instance subscription
chore(msgpack-value): add incr/decr methods to int property
chore(engine): use msgpack in exporter state
